So my head canon is Jeanette sees toddler Jaron pick up a barbie doll, and at first she internally cringes. But then she remembers how her mom gave her insecurities about her femininity, and she is reminded of some ghey news report she saw recently talking about trannies.. So from there she decides to be Mrs "unconditionally accepting" and not make a "big deal" about gender norms and expectations. Seems harmless enough and good intentioned for a dumb bish, but emotional reactive thinking like that can lead people to hell.

The movie sucks, they butchered the story so hard that contradictory shit like this is the result.

In the book, Hammond spares ALL expenses because he's a greedy fuck. Why were they stuck on the island? Why didn't they just get on a boat and leave? The movie says "muh storm" but doesn't explain why a storm should preclude getting on a boat. The book explains that Hammond had the option of building a sheltered harbor for boats, but decided that was too expensive and so the island's pier is only accessible in calm weather.

I'm not him and not part of your conversation, but it's clear that Predators has a completely different game to it than 1 or 2. In 1/2, it's dropped in and just dicks around looking for fun. It could be a right-of-passage, a bored redneck trophy hunter, who knows. But in Predators, they took their time hand-selecting the most dangerous people they could find on Earth. Not only from various countries, but even easily-missed dangers like the doctor. The entire team of prey was very carefully selected and then carted all of them out to a whole hunting planet for their game. If the first two movies were rednecks, the planet ones are like british gamesmen bringing prey to their private reserve. It's really a different game. This goes further with the social element of competing with friends and the drunk street fight they had that ended up with one strung up to sober up a bit. Going even further, it also plays into why the redneck shoots from behind without caring, while the gamesman eagerly accepts the yakuza's challenges to a sword fight.

>Director Paul Feig wears tailored suits every day on set.
Sean Connery supposedly wore bespoke Saville Row suits in most of the Bond films.
The story is that someone convinced Albert R. Broccoli or someone else in the production, that the bespoke suits would not only look better, but that the suits would hold up better than off the rack suits would, as well as provide better mobility for action sequences.
Connery had a suit made, and slept in the suit for a couple days, and the suit still looked good, so Connery wound up with bespoke suits made for the role, which I presume he kept or hot to purchase cheap at the end of the film shoots.
Bespoke Saville Row suits aren’t cheap, but they’re supposedly made for people like barristers who may spend 18 hours a day reading documents or in court, and they use the bast fabric possible.
One British Lord joked when told John Gotti wore $3,000 Armani suits, that he didn’t know you could buy a suite that cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180146365
>is bespoke the same as tailor made, or does it mean something different?
>I know there's a tier between off the rack and tailor made, where you go in for measurements and the tailor adjusts an off the rack suit to you, rather than making one from scratch. Dunno what its called though.
Bespoke means the suit is “completely Custom”.
The tailor may have forms similar to French Curves, but basically, when you get a bespoke suit made,
the tailor takes a crapload of measurements,
Then asks what type and design of suit you would like,
Then lets you choose the fabric you would like ( supposedly were the name “bespoke” comes from, since the fabric is then “spoken for”),
Then the tailor determines any special features you may want (ie. Hidden passport pocket) (extra room for a gun holster) etc.
the tailor then cuts the fabric using the measurements and possible forms, although could likely lay out the cuts freehand,
Then the fabric is sewn, routinely by hand with a needle, with all reinforcing, etc.
the buttons are hand sewn on,
The buttonholes are almost certainly hand sewn,
You then go in after the suit is sewn, or when it is just tacked together, to insure fit, which may happen twice or more.
Patterns and measurements are likely kept for future suits.

The same is done for bespoke shoes, although in those cases, custom shoe lasts may are likely made, and a pair of “pattern shoes” nay be made to insure fit.

I’m not sure what a bespoke suit costs, bit definitely in the thousands of dollars range.
John Lobb London (not the separate Hermes “John Lobb Paris”) bespoke shoes could cost up to £10,000 last time I checked.

‘The Outfit’ starring Mark Rylance shows a bit of the work.

>>180146954
>some shops will make plaster casts of your feet to keep for future shoes
Plaster casts may be made, but usually the actual last is made from wood, or maybe nowadays cast from some type of impact resistant plastic or resin like urethane.
Lazier or cheaper bespoke shoemakers buy off the rack lasts, and modify the lasts by sanding or filing material away, or by adding extra material in areas with what usually seems to be leather.
There are specialty companies for the shoe trade that make hundreds of last styles in every size, that can be purchased to avoid completely making a last. Unfortunately, these companies usually refuse to sell to the general public.

>>180141454
Watch a good adaption that cuts out a lot of the unnecessary dialogue and bullshit, where you basically can understand what's going on without understanding any of the dialogue. That will get you interested in understanding the finer meaning in the first place.

After that you do have to do a bit of homework, yes. I read the text with a translation in a column on the same page, (there's not really any other way to do it to start with), but once you get a foothold on the English of the period, it gets really fucking cool real fast. Totally worth it, (which is why Shakespeare has endured for four centuries). His use of English makes it necessary to be able to understand the language of the period to fully appreciate the man's talent. Like you could say the same thing 400 years hence about Eminem or some fag like that right?

After getting over that initial hump you can basically watch any Shakespeare film you like without needing any help.

For me it was this scene from Henry V by Kenneth Branagh that made me want to understand it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YK4K7CV_PGY

Great fucking film, and worth you time, and a million times better once you understand it fully. Also Branagh actually understands the material, knows what bullshit to cut/simplify, and delivers it in a natural way because he knows EXACTLY what he is saying. Compare that to the average faggot just reciting the words by rote and you'll fully appreciate the difference between the two.

Beyond that you need to understand the attitudes of the period, especially in relation to Christianity, man's relationship to God, etc. because there's plenty of that stuff in there. Don't worry, you pick that up in the translations.

People are turned off Shakespeare by the way they teach it in schools as a chore, and bad adaptions where they don't really get what they're saying or why, but he wrote some fucking great entertaining shit.

>>180147464
I didn't know tennis had such a long history before I read it because of Henry V. Great example of how you have to read a little history to get the full gist, and understand that old skool tennis balls were a little different to what you're otherwise thinking of. There's no way of knowing that without actually learning a few things in the process.

Also:
>'When we have matched our rackets to these balls,
>We will in France, by God’s grace, play a set
>Shall strike his father’s crown into the hazard.

Good example of exactly what I'm talking about. He's making a clever retort using old tennis references, (the 'hazard' being one of them with a double-meaning). Also note the deference to the will of God, as befitting a pious King. He wont say, "I will do x", when God might have other plans, for the same reason Moses fucked up when he drew water from the rock. You can't take credit for shit God does without being in deep spiritual shit. He never fails to do that shit the whole play, and it's pretty fucking epic part of his character, (but would make little sense if you didn't understand the religious context).

This is why you don't listen to faggots who tell you you're an idiot for not instantly understanding the language. They didn't, (no matter what they say), and you're not. You have to learn a little first. Especially when the same English words are being used in a different way. Like how could anyone out of time understand "cool" to mean anything other than it's meaning in relation to temperature right off the bat?
https://youtu.be/f1bzkpf0Ko0?t=34

After a while you can pick up a lot and get shit from the context in a 'Clockwork Orange' kinda way, just like learning any other language once you have a basis to work from.

>>180137974

Something that I always find fascinating is that you can take any field on Earth and within that field every single time there will be a micro industry of e-celebs who do nothing but create entry level introductory content about that field for NPCs to consume.

Doesn't matter if it's cooking or filmmaking or programming or whatever. There's people who actually do it. People who actually teach for real how to do it. And then a giant horde of perpetual neophytes that are in a constant churn of sort of getting into it but never having the real drive to ever actually apply themselves so they eventually drop it.

The fact that there is always a cottage industry of people like Neistat who just make content for this specific type of person is so fascinating to me. Stranger yet people like him often become incredibly wealthy and successful and are later looked at as experts within their field. But the reality is they don't have any real serious talent or skill or experience. They've simply focused on making content about the introductory levels of their field and nothing else but the audience for that is several orders of magnitude larger than anything else you could do.

Why actually make a great film or even teach masterclass filmmaking techniques when the audience for those things is so small. Compared to the amount of people with a passive interest who want to LARP like they're getting into it for a month before moving onto the next thing.

I don't know about worst, but one time I was at a horror movie film festival, and we were about to see this indiefilm from America. >>180148969
A bunch of different ways. For me, I was having major surgery and they messed up on the anesthesia leaving me awake and paralyzed for it. For some reason, my subconscious developed PTSD around falling asleep, as though it would recreate the trauma of the event. So I get anxiety attacks over falling asleep, and when I do get to sleep, I start biting my tongue hard in my sleep to wake up. After taking off a piece of the side of my tongue, I got a mouth bit, but that makes the somniphobia worse and harder to deliberately fall asleep. These days I sleep about every third day for 3-5 hours, and the time between are filled with narcoleptic episodes usually between 15 minutes and a couple of hours here and there.

>>180137706
I can look back on that style fondly since it was something weird and unique, where they took what they learned with certain readily identifiable traits and could adapt it to something distinct that could break out on what was ultimately its own terms for how they channeled it and what kind of material it incorporated. You don't get a lot of that anymore. Everything, EVERYTHING, is cross-sectioned and analyzed to make absolutely sure it's something that somebody has done before because otherwise, it's "weird" which is the 21st century equivalent of having leprosy. What I can say about Johnen Vasquez was that his style was definitely weird, indisputably weird, unabashedly weird, and it thrived on that, and that in turn reflects how much better the times were when he was able to break out.

This really got me thinking about how young people in our society are basically taught that the norms just one generation ago are totally unacceptable today. posts.name: Anonymous

>>180145349
All ideas have basis in prior ideas. Originality is an illusion. If it ever did truly exist, it died a thousand years ago. But that's okay, because cinema by nature is predicated on illusions. Suspension of disbelief is in itself an illusion, a magic trick in which you are manipulated into momentarily forgetting that none of what you are experiencing is real and that none of the characters you're invested in exist. Therefore, if something feels original to you, if it conveys a sense of freshness and unpredictability when you're watching it, even if that sense is artificial, it doesn't matter. The affectation of originality is what matters, not actually being original, which is essentially impossible.
